cases.name: Trump v. Slaughter
cases.question: Whether statutory removal protections for FTC commissioners violate the separation of powers and whether Humphrey’s Executor v. United States should be overruled.
cases.background: Trump fired FTC Commissioner Rebecca Slaughter without cause in March 2025, directly challenging the 1935 Humphrey’s Executor precedent that allows Congress to insulate independent agency leaders from at-will presidential removal. Six conservative justices signaled openness to overruling the 90-year precedent during oral arguments.
firstOrder: Presidents gain power to fire and replace members of ~24 independent agencies (FTC, EEOC, NLRB, SEC, FCC, etc.) at will
Bipartisan commission structure effectively ends — no requirement for ideological balance
Humphrey’s Executor (1935) overruled, removing 90 years of precedent insulating agencies from political control
secondOrder: Regulatory policy swings wildly with each administration — businesses face uncertainty as rules are made, unmade, and remade every 4 years
Agencies lose institutional expertise as career commissioners are replaced by political loyalists without domain knowledge
Foreign governments and investors lose confidence in U.S. regulatory stability, affecting trade agreements and capital flows
Congress may attempt to reclaim direct regulatory authority, leading to legislative gridlock on issues currently handled by agencies

cases.name: Trump v. Cook
cases.question: Whether the president can remove Federal Reserve governors without cause, and whether the Fed’s unique structure warrants a carve-out from any ruling on independent agencies.
cases.background: Trump attempted to fire Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook shortly after the Court carved out an apparent exception for the Fed in its Slaughter-related stay orders. Cook challenged the removal. The case tests whether central bank independence — considered vital to monetary policy stability — survives any expansion of presidential removal power.
firstOrder: Presidents could fire and replace Federal Reserve governors to install allies aligned with political goals
Fed’s ability to set interest rates independently of electoral pressures is compromised
Central bank credibility — the foundation of inflation expectations management — is directly threatened
secondOrder: Bond markets reprice U.S. sovereign debt as investors factor in politicized monetary policy, raising borrowing costs for government and consumers
Dollar’s reserve currency status weakens as global actors question Fed credibility, accelerating de-dollarization trends
Presidents face temptation to push for low rates before elections, creating boom-bust cycles timed to political calendars
Other nations’ central banks reconsider bilateral agreements and currency swaps with a politically captured Fed

cases.name: Kinkley v. United States
cases.question: Whether the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) authorizes the President to impose tariffs.
cases.background: Small businesses and 12 states challenged Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ tariffs as exceeding presidential authority under IEEPA. No president has previously used IEEPA to impose tariffs. The Court of International Trade and Federal Circuit both ruled against Trump. Justices appeared skeptical of the tariffs’ legality during oral arguments.
firstOrder: If struck down: $100B+ in collected tariffs may need to be refunded; tariff regime collapses overnight
If upheld: presidents gain virtually unlimited power to impose tariffs without congressional approval under emergency declarations
Either outcome redefines the boundary between congressional trade authority and executive emergency powers
secondOrder: If struck down: supply chains that reshored based on tariff assumptions face stranded investment costs; Congress pressured to pass statutory tariffs
If upheld: future presidents (of any party) can weaponize IEEPA for economic policy — tariffs, sanctions, capital controls — creating permanent uncertainty for global trade
Trading partners accelerate diversification away from U.S. market dependence regardless of outcome
Major questions doctrine is either strengthened (limiting executive overreach) or shown to have limits of its own

cases.name: NRSC v. FEC
cases.question: Whether federal limits on coordinated campaign expenditures between political parties and candidates violate the First Amendment, reconsidering FEC v. Colorado Republican (2001).
cases.background: The National Republican Senatorial Committee and others argue that the Court’s 2001 decision upholding limits on coordinated party spending should be overturned in light of more recent First Amendment jurisprudence tightening restrictions on campaign finance regulation.
firstOrder: Parties can spend unlimited amounts in direct coordination with their candidates’ campaigns
Distinction between ‘independent’ and ‘coordinated’ expenditures effectively disappears for parties
FEC’s enforcement framework for party coordination limits becomes unenforceable
secondOrder: Power consolidates back to party leadership — candidates become more dependent on party apparatus, reducing maverick and independent-minded legislators
Dark money flows shift: donors route through party structures instead of Super PACs, changing accountability dynamics
Smaller third parties gain no benefit (lack fundraising infrastructure), widening the two-party advantage
State-level campaign finance laws modeled on federal coordination limits face immediate legal challenges

cases.name: Louisiana v. Callais
cases.question: Whether Louisiana’s creation of a second majority-Black congressional district constitutes an unconstitutional racial gerrymander under the 14th and 15th Amendments.
cases.background: The Court was unable to reach a decision in the 2024–25 term and rescheduled the case. Conservative justices appeared sympathetic to arguments that race played too large a role in redistricting. The case pits the Voting Rights Act’s Section 2 requirements against the Equal Protection Clause.
firstOrder: States may no longer be required (or allowed) to draw majority-minority districts to comply with the Voting Rights Act
Section 2 of the VRA is functionally gutted as a redistricting tool — states can’t use race even to remedy discrimination
Louisiana’s second Black-majority district is struck down, reducing Black representation in Congress
secondOrder: Nationwide redistricting wave: states redraw maps to eliminate existing majority-minority districts, shifting 10–20 congressional seats
Voting Rights Act becomes a hollow statute — unable to compel redistricting remedies, its enforcement mechanism collapses
Civil rights organizations pivot strategy from courts to ballot initiatives and grassroots organizing
Paradox: race can’t be used to remedy discrimination but partisan gerrymandering (which correlates with race) remains legal, entrenching structural disadvantage

cases.name: Dept. of Education v. California
cases.question: Whether the administration can proceed with slashing Education Department workforce while legal challenges continue.
cases.background: The Supreme Court vacated a district court order requiring reinstatement of terminated grants and allowed the administration to proceed with cutting over a third of the Education Department workforce. Justice Sotomayor issued a dissenting opinion calling it a major expansion of presidential power.
firstOrder: Executive can proceed with large-scale agency downsizing while legal challenges are still pending
District courts’ ability to preserve the status quo via injunctions is weakened on the emergency docket
Education Department loses institutional capacity that may be impossible to rebuild even if courts later rule the cuts unlawful
secondOrder: Template established for dismantling other agencies — future administrations can slash first, litigate later, knowing the Court won’t intervene
Federal employees across all agencies face chilling effect: institutional knowledge holders leave voluntarily, anticipating cuts
States must absorb functions previously handled by federal Education Dept., creating unfunded mandates and regional inequality
Irreversibility problem becomes the norm: by the time courts rule, the harm is done and there’s no practical remedy
